metadata.case_name: Appellants (illegitimate son and daughter of Sardarni Prem Prakash Kaur) v. Respondents

facts.text: Appellants are the illegitimate son and daughter of Sardarni Prem Prakash Kaur.
By registered deed of sale dated December 1, 1956, Sardarni Prem Prakash Kaur sold 18 bighas, 1 biswas and 5-1/2 biswansis of agricultural land for Rs. 10,000/- to the respondents.
Appellants filed a suit to pre-empt this sale. There was some dispute about the consideration actually paid but the court is not concerned with it.
Both the trial court and the District Court on appeal granted the appellants a decree for pre-emption, though to a limited extent.
Respondents filed a second appeal to the Punjab High Court in Regular Second Appeal No. 837 of 1960.

Punjab High Court by judgment and decree dated February 1961 directed dismissal of the suit on the ground that appellants were not comprehended within s.15(2)(b) of the Punjab Pre-emption Act as amended by Act X of 1960.
Present appeal by special leave from the Punjab High Court judgment.

legal_issues.text: Do the words 'son or daughter of such female' occurring in s.15(2)(b) of the Punjab Preemption Act, 1913 as amended by Act X of 1960 include an illegitimate son or illegitimate daughter of such female?

petitioner_arguments.text: The provision in s.15 of the Pre-emption Act must be read in conjunction with the Hindu Succession Act, 1956 which made provision for the devolution of property belonging to a female owner and that as under the latter enactment illegitimate children of a Hindu female were entitled to succeed to her property, it must be held that when the Punjab legislature used in 1960 the expression 'son or daughter' it meant a son or a daughter who would be entitled to succeed as an heir of a Hindu female.

respondent_arguments.text: Appellants were not comprehended within the class of persons who were entitled to pre-emption under s.15(2)(b) of the Punjab Pre-emption Act as it stands under the amendment effected by Act X of 1960.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Punjab Pre-emption Act, 1913 s.15(2)(b) as amended by Act X of 1960

court_reasoning.text: Submission to read s.15 with Hindu Succession Act untenable; framers did not proceed on theory of heirs under Hindu Succession Act. Example: under s.15(2)(a), right vests in brother or brother's son, different from Hindu Succession Act devolution.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Theory to resort to line of heirs under Hindu Succession Act untenable.

court_reasoning.text: If female vendor Christian, only legitimate issue denoted; statutory right applies equally to all, construction cannot depend on religion or changes in personal law.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Construction would vary with vendor's religion or changes in intestate succession law, unsustainable.

court_reasoning.text: Normal rule of construction: words 'child, son or daughter' in statute include only legitimate children born in wedlock. No express provision or context to extend to illegitimate; s.3(j) Hindu Succession Act illustrates express extension.
Words 'son or daughter' occur multiple times in s.15; for male vendor, conceded to mean legitimate only. Cannot differ for female vendor. Brother's son in s.15(2)(a)(i) means legitimate.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Context confirms legitimate only; too clear for argument.

holdings.text: When s.15(2)(b)(i) uses the words 'son or daughter' it meant only a legitimate son and a legitimate daughter of the female vendor.

statutes_cited.name: Punjab Pre-emption Act, 1913
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines persons in whom right of pre-emption vests; key phrase 'son or daughter of such female' in s.15(2)(b) interpreted to mean legitimate only.

statutes_cited.name: Hindu Succession Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Petitioners argued to read with Pre-emption Act for succession rights including illegitimate; court rejected. s.3(j) illustrates express inclusion of illegitimate.

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court upheld the Punjab High Court's judgment directing dismissal of the appellants' suit for pre-emption, holding that illegitimate son and daughter are not included in 'son or daughter' under s.15(2)(b) of the Punjab Pre-emption Act, 1913 as amended.

key_quotes.text: Do the words son or daughter of such female occurring in s.15(2)(b) of the Punjab Preemption Act, 1913 as amended by Act X of 1960 include an illegitimate son or illegitimate daughter of such female is the only question that arises in this appeal by special leave.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: That the normal rule of construction of the words child, son or daughter occurring in a statute would include only legitimate children i.e., born in wedlock, is too elementary to require authority.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: States the primary rule of interpretation applied.

key_quotes.text: The matter appears to us to be too clear for argument that when s.15(2)(b)(i) uses the words son or daughter it meant only a legitimate son and a legitimate daughter of the female vendor.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Concludes the holding rejecting appellants' claim.
